Affect (Option B)

Expression of mood (emotions) in terms of facial expressions and body language.

Internal phenomenon

questions.text: Which method is often used in clinical settings to evaluate recent memory?
questions.explanation:
Immediate memory/ Short-term memory

Recent Memory

Remote Memory

The ability to hold and manipulate information temporarily while performing cognitive tasks.

The ability to recall information or events that have occurred recently, typically within the last few days or weeks.

The ability to recall information or events from the distant past, often years or decades ago.

Seconds

Minutes, hours to days

Months, Years to a lifetime

Eg- Solving a math problem in your head, remembering a phone number long enough to dial it.

Eg- Recalling a conversation from earlier today or remembering what you ate for breakfast.

Eg-Remembering childhood experiences or significant historical events.

Test for concentration and attention to assess immediate memory.

Digit Span Test, n-back task, and mental arithmetic tasks.

24-Hour Recall Method, Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT).

Autobiographical memory questioning,asking personal information.

questions.text: Which test is commonly done to assess concentration in a person?
questions.explanation:
Concentration

Orientation

Attention

Cognitive ability to focus one's mental efforts on a specific task, stimulus, or activity for an extended period while ignoring irrelevant information or distractions.

Awareness of oneself in relation to time, place, and person.

Cognitive process of selectively concentrating on specific aspects of the environment while ignoring others.

It involves:

  • Sustained mental focus
  • Efficient information processing
  • Resisting cognitive fatigue

Components:

  • Temporal Orientation: Understanding the time.
  • Spatial Orientation: Awareness of one’s position in relation to the environment.
  • Personal Orientation: Recognition of one’s identity.

It involves

  • Focusing on relevant stimuli
  • Sustaining concentration over time
  • Dividing focus between multiple tasks
  • Shifting focus when needed

Assessment method:

Serial 7s Subtraction Method:

Procedure:

  • The subject starts with a number (typically 100).
  • They subtract 7 repeatedly, stating each result aloud.
  • This continues for a set number of subtractions or a specific time period.

Example sequence: 100, 93, 86, 79, 72, 65.

Assessment: Often evaluated through direct questioning and observation.

Questioning like:

  • What is your name?
  • Who am I?
  • What place is this?
  • Where is it located?

Assessment Methods:

  • Continuous Performance Test (CPT)
  • Trail Making Test
  • Stroop Color and Word Test
  • Digit Span Test- Digit forward(option B) and Digit backward test.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a delusion, not a hallucination?

options.label: A
options.text: Hearing voices telling you to harm yourself

options.label: B
options.text: Believing that you are being followed by secret agents without any evidence

options.label: C
options.text: Seeing people who are not present

options.label: D
options.text: Smelling smoke when there is none

questions.correct_answer: B. Believing that you are being followed by secret agents without any evidence
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Delusions

Hallucinations

Definition

Fixed, false beliefs that are resistant to reasoning or contrary evidence.

False sensory perceptions without external stimuli.

Nature

Cognitive in nature; involves thought processes.

Sensory in nature; involves the senses (sight, sound, touch, etc.)

Examples

Believing one is being persecuted (delusion of persecution) or is famous (grandeur).

Hearing voices, seeing things that are not present, or feeling sensations on the skin.

Perception of Reality

Individuals may be convinced of their beliefs despite clear evidence against them.

Individuals experience sensations as real, even though they are not.

Associated Conditions

Commonly seen in schizophrenia, delusional disorder.

Common in schizophrenia, psychotic disorders, neurological conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after experiencing disorientation and confusion. He describes when he looks in the mirror, he cannot see his own reflection. This phenomenon is best described as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Type of Hallucination

Description

Associated Conditions

Reflex Hallucination

A hallucination in one sensory modality triggered by a stimulus in another sensory modality (e.g- hearing a sound when seeing a light)

Sensory processing disorders

Functional Hallucination

A real external stimulus coexists with a hallucination in the same modality (e.g hearing voices while listening to real external sounds)

Schizophrenia, psychosis

Extracampine Hallucination

(Option C)

Perception of an object or sensation outside the normal sensory field (e.g hearing someone talking behind you when no one is present)

Schizophrenia

Autoscopy

Seeing one’s own body or image from an external perspective.

Also known as Phantom mirror-image

 

Negative autoscopy- Not seeing one’s reflection in the mirror being present.

 

Internal autoscopy- person can see his own internal organs.(Option B)

Can occur in schizophrenia, but more common in delirium.

Other condition: Temporal lobe epilepsy

Hypnagogic Hallucination

(Option D)

Hallucinations occurring during the transition from wakefulness to sleep.

Narcolepsy

Hypnopompic Hallucination

Hallucinations occurring during the transition from sleep to wakefulness.

Narcolepsy

Organic Hallucinations

Hallucinations can occur in any sensory modality and are caused by an identifiable physical condition.

Neurological disorders, substance abuse, brain lesions.

Charles Bonnet syndrome: consists of visual hallucinations (no other psychiatric symptom) and reduced vision due to eye disease.

questions.text: A 10-year boy was brought by his mother to a psychiatric clinic. She says that the boy has been complaining of headaches and behaves abnormally saying that he stays silent most of the time and becomes violent occasionally for the last 1 month, his academic grades have dropped drastically, and his teachers have complained about his aggressive behavior towards other children in school. There is a history of falls a few months back for which the clinician ordered a CT brain and the report is as follows What group of disorders would you classify this patient’s condition under?
questions.explanation:
Organic disorders:
  • Psychiatric symptoms following a demonstrable/apparent cause.
  • Most common cause: metabolic encephalopathies (presents with altered sensorium/behavior)
  • Routine investigations to be done: CT/MRI Brain, serum investigations, CSF analysis (if required)
  • History of head injury may be present in cases of hematoma, etc.

Functional disorders:
  • Psychiatric symptoms are present without any demonstrable apparent cause.
  • More commonly seen.
  • Further classified into two categories:
    • Neurosis: intact insight and judgment.
    • Psychosis: impaired insight and judgment.

questions.text: Match the following clinical scenarios with their appropriate grade of insight 1) Grade-I a) A 60 year male who has been diagnosed with narcolepsy, says that he has this condition because he lives in Shimla. 2) Grade-II b) 40 year old male who was a chronic smoker decided to give up smoking, attends rehabilitation sessions, takes medications and is focused on improving his lifestyle. 3) Grade-III c) Female patient says that she is a known case of bipolar disorder, but refuses to take medications. 4) Grade-IV d) 25 year old female who has been admitted to a psychiatric ward for schizophrenia says that she has come to the hospital for fever and cough and denies any psychiatric illness. 5) Grade-V
questions.explanation:
Grade-I

Complete denial of illness

Grade-II

Slight awareness of being ill and denying at the same time

Grade-III

Awareness of illness is present, but the patient attributes the disease to other external/medical/unknown organic factors.

Grade-IV

Awareness of illness is due to his/her own irrational feelings or emotions but the patient refuses to apply this knowledge to change his/her behavior.

Also known as intellectual insight.

Grade-V

Awareness of illness is due to his/her own irrational feelings or emotions and the patient agrees to apply this knowledge to change his/her behavior.

questions.text: The clinician asked a patient ‘You see a person bleeding profusely on the roadside, what would you do?’, the patient replied ‘I would make another cut with a knife on him’. What type of judgment is being evaluated here and what is the likely pathology?
questions.correct_answer: C. Impairment of test judgment - schizophrenia
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Example

Social
  • Social behavior of the patient in day-to-day routine events.
  • Contrary to acceptable behavior in culture.

Harmful behavior, like rash driving, fighting without a reason, or other unacceptable behavior.

Personal
  • The ability of a patient to take care of one’s own self.
  • Categorized under social judgment.

If a patient says to start working again and continue with his normal life after discharge from the hospital suggests intact personal judgment. On the contrary, if he says he will buy a gun and start shooting people, indicates impaired personal judgment.

Test
  • Patient’s prediction of what they would do in hypothetical situations. (Option C)
  • An imaginary scenario is asked by the clinician and the reply is assessed.

The clinician asked a patient ‘You see a person bleeding profusely on the roadside, what would you do?’, the patient replied ‘I would make another cut with a knife on him’ indicates impaired test judgment, seen in Schizophrenia. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following tasks is most commonly used to assess abstract thinking abilities?
questions.explanation:
Abstract Thinking

Intelligence

The ability to understand concepts that are not tied to concrete objects or experiences; involves reasoning about ideas, principles, and relationships.

Broader construct that encompasses various cognitive abilities, including reasoning, problem-solving, learning, and adaptation to new situations.

Components:

  • Pattern recognition
  • Problem-solving skills
  • Conceptualization
  • Logical reasoning

Components:

  • Logical reasoning
  • Verbal comprehension
  • Quantitative reasoning
  • Spatial visualization

Assessment Methods:

  • Raven's Progressive Matrices
  • Proverb testing
  • Similarity testing

Assessment Methods:

  • Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS)
  • Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales

Example:

When asked the meaning of the proverb, "A stitch in time saves nine," a person explains that it means solving a small problem early can prevent it from becoming a bigger issue. This shows an ability to grasp the underlying concept rather than just the literal meaning.

Example:

Navigating daily life challenges by adapting, learning, and making decisions also reflects intelligence.

questions.text: On psychiatric evaluation, a 30-year-old female when asked about what she did that morning. Said “ I went to a supermarket, the supermarket's logo was in yellow color, which reminded me of the sun. I like the sun a lot more than the moon. I don’t understand how the astronauts are able to go to the moon with such pathetic costumes…..” went on to talk about it for a long period in a rapid pressurized manner. What term best describes the patient’s presentation?

Correctly match the following statements with True(T)/ False(F) 1) Continuity is disrupted in tangentiality 2) Goal is not reached in circumstantiality 3) Perseveration is associated with organic mental disorder 4) Continuity is preserved in perseveration 5) Thought blocking is associated with schizophrenia
questions.explanation:
Continuity maintained with increased speed:
  • Flight of ideas: rapid flow of ideas from one to another, connected and partially understandable
  • Prolixity: Milder form of flight of ideas
  • Clang association: sentences with rhyming

Continuity maintained with decreased speed: (Statement-1)
  • Thought slowing/retardation: Decrease in speed of thought, seen in depression
  • Circumstantiality: Overinclusion of trivial and unnecessary details, but ultimately reaches the answer. (Statement-2)
  • Tangentiality: Flow of irrelevant thoughts that deviates from the main topic and never reaches the answer.

Continuity disrupted:

  • Perseveration: (Statement-4)
    • Same thought persists beyond the point of relevance.
    • Pathological repetition of the same response to different stimuli.
    • Seen in organic mental disorder (Statement-3) and schizophrenia.
  • Thought blocking:
    • Sudden arrest of thought and then the person resumes with an entirely new thought.
    • Seen in schizophrenia. (Statement-5)

Hypochondriacal delusion/Delusion of ill health
  • Characteristically seen in depression, may also be seen in schizophrenia.

Various forms of Hypochondriacal delusion:

Delusion of Infestation/ Parasitosis/ Ekbom syndrome:

  • Patient falsely believes that he is infested with insects,he does not experience sensation.
  • It affects both men and women equally and becomes more common with age.
  • ‘Empty matchbox sign’ may be present (when the patient attempts to catch the insect to show it to the clinician).

Delusional dysmorphophobia:

  • Patient believes that his body/part of his body is deformed and wants it to be corrected.

Delusional halitosis:

  • Belief that the patient has a malodorous body odor.

Mood-congruent delusion

Mood-incongruent delusion
  • Content of delusion that is consistent with the patient’s mood.
  • Content of delusion that has no relation to the patient’s mood.
  • E.g., depressed patients who believe that they are responsible for the destruction of the world.
  • E.g., depressed patients who believe that they are the new Messiah.

questions.text: A 35 y/o man insists that his wife has been replaced by an identical imposter, despite her behavior and appearance remaining unchanged. He is convinced that the person living with him is not his real wife. What syndrome is he most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Misidentification syndrome

Capgras Syndrome

(Option B)

Belief that a close person (often a family member) has been replaced by an identical double.

Fregoli Syndrome

(Option A ruled out)
  • Belief that various people are actually the same person in disguise.
  • Eg. Patient believes her neighbor could change appearance, clothes and sex to spy on her.

Intermetamorphosis Syndrome

Delusion that people have swapped identities but kept their physical appearance.

Subjective Doubles Syndrome

(Option D ruled out)

Belief that the patient has a double or doppelganger.

Reduplicative Paramnesia

(Option C ruled out)

Delusional belief that identical places or events exist.

Hallucination

Pseudo-hallucination

Definition

A false perception combining a real stimulus with a mental image

Stimulus

No external stimulus

Insight

The individual may or may not realize the misinterpretation

Often lacks insight

Associated Conditions

Not necessarily pathological; can occur in normal individuals or in conditions like delirium

Usually indicates a serious mental illness, such as schizophrenia or psychosis

Can occur in mental illness

Mistaking a shadow for an attacker on a dark road

Hearing voices that are perceived as coming from other people when no one is speaking

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is asked, "What is the color of grass?" and responds, "White." When asked, "What is the color of snow?" the patient replies, "Green." This type of response, where the patient understands the question but provides incorrect yet related answers, is most likely an example of which phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Abnormal thought process

Talking Past the Point (Vorbeireden)

(Option D)
  • Patient responds with incorrect answers related to the topic, despite understanding the question.
  • Example: Saying "white" for grass color and "green" for snow color.
  • Seen in hysterical pseudodementia (dissociative disorder) and Ganser’s syndrome (approximate answers).
  • Also occurs in acute schizophrenia, especially in adolescents (hebephrenia).

Loosening of Associations

(Option A ruled out)
  • Disorganized thought progression, shifting between unrelated topics, leading to incoherent communication.

Derailment
  • Sudden or gradual deviation in thought (without blocking), often used synonymously with loosening of associations.

Incoherence
  • Disconnected, disorganized, or incomprehensible speech.
  • Word Salad: Incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.(Option C ruled out)

Word Approximation

(Option B ruled out)
  • Using conventional words in an unconventional way (e.g., "hand shoes" for gloves)
  • Distinguished from a neologism, which is a newly created word with an unclear or unknown origin.

questions.text: A 30 y/o man with schizophrenia is noted to use the word "skycar" to describe an airplane and "watercar" to refer to a boat. He also invents new words when trying to explain his experiences. Which of the following best describes his speech pattern?
questions.explanation:
Neologism

Neologisms
  • New words or ordinary words used in a new way, often linked to schizophrenia.
  • Neologisms can result from:
    • Completely new words with no clear derivation.
    • Distorted versions of existing words.
    • Words formed incorrectly using normal word-formation rules.

Causes of Neologisms
  • Formal thought disorder: Fusing words or concepts together.
  • Derailment: Using incorrect words, e.g., "relativity" instead of "relationship."
  • Technical neologisms: Words invented for private, unexplainable experiences.
  • Hallucinatory Voices: Voices may influence neologisms, forcing the patient to create new words to communicate or defend.

Catatonia & Neologisms

Neologisms may be linked to stereotyped movements or mannerisms, distorting word pronunciation.

Stock Words

Using one word repeatedly in different contexts (e.g., "air car" for airplane, "sea car" for boat). (Option B)

Paraphasia

Seen in motor aphasia, where wrong or invented words resemble neologisms. (Option A ruled out)

Malapropisms

Misused words that resemble neologisms but have no psychiatric significance. (Option C ruled out)

Word Approximation
  • Using conventional words in an unconventional way (e.g., "hand shoes" for gloves)
  • Distinguished from a neologism, which is a newly created word with an unclear or unknown origin. (Option D ruled out)
